availability.licence: This description is released under a CC0 licence.

msItem.author: John Mirk
msItem.title: Manuale sacerdotis

msItem.rubric: (fol. 1r) Incipit prefatio libelli qui dicitur manuale sacerdotis.
msItem.incipit: Amico suo karissimo domino Iohanni de S. uicario de A. frater Iohannes dictus prior de Lileshul salutem in auctore salutis. Ex uerbis domini saluatoris

msItem.rubric: Incipit prima pars huius libelli De eo quod sacerdos qui immaculatus ordines suos recipit per uiam salutis ad regnum tendit.
msItem.incipit: (fol. 3r) Inter melliflua sancti psalterii cantica tangens cordam
msItem.explicit: (fol. 129v) ad laudem et gloriam domini nostri Ihesu Christi. Cui est honor et gloria per infinita seculorum secula. Amen.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit libellus dictus manuale sacerdotis secundum Iohannem Marcus priorem abathiae de Lilyshel.

msItem.rubric: (fol. 130r) Hec est tabula istius libri Capitula prime partis huius libelli.
msItem.incipit: 1. Quod sacerdos qui ordines suos immaculatus recipit per uiam salutis ad regnum tendit.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit tabula totius libri qui dicitur manuale sacerdotis.

msItem.note: ed. J. M. Girsch, ‘An edition with commentary of John Mirk’s Manuale sacerdotis’ PhD diss. (Toronto 1990); Bloomfield 2787; A. J. Fletcher, ‘The manuscripts of John Mirk’s Manuale sacerdotis’, Leeds Studies in English, new ser. 19 (1988), pp. 105–39.
Blank, sporadic notes and pen trials in several hands from 134v onwards.

supportDesc.foliation: Foliation in modern pencil on the upper right corner from 1 to 137, skipping a folio between 94 and 95 and counting the endleaves.
supportDesc.collation: 1–168 178 (wants 7th) + z4 (wants 4th). Quire signatures, denoting the quire and folio respectively (e.g. ‘a3’), in the first four leaves of quires 1–12 and then sporadically at the lower right corner. Catchwords at the bottom right hand of the each final verso. habere sanctam

layoutDesc.layout: Pricked in the outer margins, ruled in crayon, 18 long lines. Ruled space 85 65

handDesc.handNote: A single medium-quality anglicana formata hand.

decoDesc.decoNote: Blue initials with typical red flourishes.
Small capitals in text are sometimes highlighted in red.

binding.p: 15th-cent., leather on boards, sewn on three raised bands, no endbands. Holes for two catch plates in the bottom cover.

history.provenance: Apparent 15th-cent. pressmarks: number I manuale sacerdotis (paper pastedown); 37 (fol. 1); Num. I (fol. 1); (80) (fol. 1).
Liber Domini David, second half of the 15th cent. or first half of the 16th cent. (fol. iii recto).
The above wryttyng is the hand of William Jankyn, 16th cent. (fol. ii verso).
William David Morgan is the true owner of this booke, 17th cent., cancelled (fol. 104r).
history.acquisition: The manuscript had entered the College by 1649, as it appears in Mansell’s account as Liber Collectionum – Manuale Sacerdotis. (Jesus College Archives, College Register of Dr F. Mansell, 1649, p. 11.) The transfer probably happened not much before that year because the seventeenth-century individuals in inscriptions are not recorded in J. Foster, The Members of the University of Oxford 1500–1714 (Oxford, 1891–2). The names hint that the book came into the possession of the College from Wales. Pressmarks: spine: ‘J. Arch. S–J’, 17th cent. (paper label); ‘MS. Jesus Coll. Ox. F. 1.’, 20th cent. (paper label).

source.p: Description by Samu Niskanen (January 2011), revised by Andrew Dunning (December 2022). Previously described:

listBibl.bibl: H. O. Coxe, Catalogus codicum mss. qui in collegiis aulisque Oxoniensibus hodie adservantur (1852)

revisionDesc.change: Andrew Dunning revised description by Samu Niskanen.
